div.p: A CASE OF CONSCIENCE Re≈øolved.
Wherein it is cleared, That the KING may without impeachment to his Oath, touching the Clergy at Coronation, con≈øent to the Abrogation of EPISCOPACY.
AND The OBIECTIONS again≈øt it in two learned Treati≈øes, Printed at Oxford, Fully An≈øwered.
By JOHN GEREE Ma≈øter of Arts, and Preacher of the word of God at St. Albanes.
LONDON, Printed by Matthew Simmons, for John Bartlet, at the Guilt-Cup at Au≈øtines-Gate, 1646.
Que≈øtion 1.
WHether the King (con≈øidering his Oath at Coronation to protect the Clergy and their Priviledges) can ≈øalv√¢ con≈øcienti√¢ con≈øent to the abrogation of Epi≈øcopacy?

When I con≈øider, fir≈øt, That there is no hope of the Kings or Kingdomes ≈øafety, without an union between our King and Parliament. Secondly, that ≈øuch an union is tantum non impo≈ø≈øible, unle≈ø≈øe the King conde≈øcend in the point of Epi≈øcopacy. Thirdly, for the King to conde≈øcend renitente con≈øeienti√¢, though it might gratifie us, it would be ≈øinfull to him, and ≈øo he ≈øhould forfeit inward to procure outward peace, and be repre≈øented to times in the gla≈ø≈øe of Con≈øcience, to adventure the Heavenly to retaine an earthly Crowne. Fourthly, the Oath taken at the Kings Coronation hath been pre≈øt by ≈øome learned pens with that probablity, that may ≈øtumble a right intelligent Reader, neither have they that I know, received any ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer in print. I conceive it may be a work worthy ≈øome paines to re≈øolve this ca≈øe, and cleere your objections, that while they ≈øtand unan≈øwered, ca≈øt an ill reflexion both upon the King in conde≈øcending to abrogate Epi≈øcopacie, and the Parliament in pre≈ø≈øing him to it. Now the bond of the Kings Oath may be taken off two wayes. Either by cleering the unlawfulne≈ø≈øe of it that it was vinculum iniquitatis, and ≈øo voide the fir≈øt day, for qui jurat in iniquum obligatur in contrarium. And if Prelacy in the Church be an u≈øurpation contrary to Chri≈øts in≈øtitution, then to maintaine it is to ≈øinne, and all bonds to ≈øinne are fru≈øtrate. And truly, as Prelacy ≈øtood with us in England, ingro≈ø≈øing all ruledome in the Church into the hands of a few Lord Bi≈øhops, I thinke it may be cleered to be an u≈øurpation by this one Argument. That Power that de≈øpoyles any of Chri≈øts Officers of any Priviledge, or duty indulged or injoyned them by the word of God; that power is an u≈øurpation again≈øt the word. But this Prelacy did, as it ≈øtood in England. Ergo, Engli≈øh Prelacy was
an u≈øurpation again≈øt the word of God. The Major is cleere of it ≈øelf. The Minor is thus proved. Presbyters are by Chri≈øts warrant in Scripture indued with power to rule in their owne Congregations, as well as preach; ≈øee 1 Tim. 3.5. and 5.21. Heb. 13.17. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 5.12.

Now as Prelacy ≈øtood in England, the Presbyters were not onely excluded from all ≈øociety in Rule, but which was much more prejudiciall to the dignity, and liberty of the Mini≈øtery, were ≈øubjected to a lay Chancelour; and was not here u≈øurpation again≈øt Gods direction?

But though this way of invalidating the Kings Oath be mo≈øt ≈øatisfactory to ≈øome, yet to tho≈øe that are not convinc't of the unlawfulne≈ø≈øe of Epi≈øcopacy it will not hold, and ≈øo it would ca≈øt the re≈øolution of this doubt about the Oath, upon another Que≈øtion touching the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of Epi≈øcopacy, which is a larger field. I ≈øhall therefore indeavour to ≈øhew that though for Argument ≈øake it be granted that Epi≈øcopacy be lawfull, yet notwith≈øtanding that his Oath, the King without impeachment may in this circum≈øtance con≈øent to the abrogation of Epi≈øcopacy.

The u≈øuall way of cleering this a≈ø≈øertion is thus. The King is ≈øworne to maintaine the Lawes of the Land in force at his Coronation. Yet no man que≈øtions, and the con≈øtant practi≈øe ≈øhewes; that it is not unlawfull after to abrogate any upon the motion or with the con≈øent of his Parliament. The meaning of the Oath being knowne to be to maintaine the Lawes while they are Lawes, but when they are abrogated by ju≈øt power in a regular way, they are then wiped out of his charge and Oath. So the King by his Oath is bound to maintaine the rights of the Clergy while they continue ≈øuch. But if any of their rights be abrogated by ju≈øt power, he ≈øtands no longer ingaged to that particular: And this I conceive to be a ≈øound re≈øolution. For the Kings Oath is again≈øt acting or ≈øuffering a tyrannous inva≈øion on Lawes and rights, not again≈øt a Parliamentary alteration of either.

A namele≈ø≈øe Author in a Book impleading all war again≈øt the King.But here ≈øteps in my fir≈øt opponent, and though he di≈øpute mode≈øtly, onely propo≈øing what he holds forth to ≈øerious con≈øideration, yet he objects ≈øubtlely and his di≈øcour≈øe runs thus. The Oath for maintenance of Lawes is made populo Anglicano to the people of England, and ≈øo may be taken off by a future Act, becau≈øe it is by their owne
con≈øent repre≈øented in Parliament. But the Oath to maintaine the priviledges of the Clergy, is made to ≈øuch a part of his people clero Anglicano, and particularly taken by him after his Oath to the whole Realme, which were needle≈ø≈øe unle≈ø≈øe it meant ≈øome other obligation. This ≈øeems (≈øaith the learned Author) to make it a di≈øtinct obligation, and not relea≈øable without the Clergies con≈øent.

I an≈øwer. Taking it for granted that the Oath is thus taken by the King. That Oath was ≈øo framed, when Clerus Anglicanus the Clergy of England, was a di≈øtinct ≈øociety or Corporation (as I may ≈øo ≈øay) √† populo Anglicano, from the people of England. This di≈øtinction between the Clergy and Laity we may ob≈øerve in our Hi≈øtorians. Daniel in the life of William the fir≈øt, gives this for a rea≈øon why the Clergy did ≈øo willingly conde≈øcend to him, becau≈øe they had their Province apart, whence they ≈øuppo≈øed a ≈øecurity to their Priviledges, however the Laity were in≈ølaved. Dan. in the life of William the fir≈øt, pag. 36. The ≈øame di≈øtinction of the Clergie and Laity is ob≈øerved by him in the life of Henry the ≈øecond, pag. 83. And this was not onely in England, but in other Nations, as it is ob≈øerved by Mar≈øilius Patavinus a Learned writer in Popi≈øh times. Secularium petentes fa≈øtigia in legum lationes ≈øeor≈øum ab iis quae Civium univer≈øitatis proruperunt: omnem Clei ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ abbine decernentes exemptum: Civile ≈øebi≈ømas, & principatuum ≈øupremorum pluralitatem inducentes ex lip≈øis, quam velut impo≈ø≈øibilem humane quieti certam ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ jus inducentes experientiam demon≈øtravimus 17o. 1
‚Ä¢ . Mar≈øilius Patavinus defen≈øi pacis, part. 2. cap. 23.Hence are they ≈øtiled by Tindall in his practi≈øe of Popi≈øh Prelates, corpus neutrum. Now being the Clergy and Laity were di≈øtinct bodies; the Clergie holding their rights by Priviledge di≈øtinct from the Lawes of the Land; an Oath to maintaine the Lawes of the Land ≈øecured not them: But as another body they had another Oath for their ≈øecurity. But now this di≈øtinction of the Clergie from the Laity, that they ≈øhould be a di≈øtinct Province of them≈øelves, being a branch of Popery, is with it quite extingui≈øht: And Laity and Clergie are now one body Politick, and under the ≈øame power and Rule. For all priviledges of the Clergie that are contrariant to the Lawes of the Land, were aboli≈øht in the reigne of Henry the eight. As undoubtedly that was, that any ≈øociety ≈øhould be exempt from ≈øecular power, for that was to ≈øet up two Supremacies. And therefore though the Oath be continued in that order that it was when the Laity and Clergie were di≈øtinct bodies; yet now that this di≈øtinction is abrogated,
and they are made one, the oath to the Clergie cannot be ≈øtronger or more inviolable, then that to the Layetie for the pre≈øervation of the Lawes of the Land. Both ≈øubject to regular alteration.

Who knowes not that one of the priviledges of the Clergie was, for the Bi≈øhops to ≈øit and vote in the hou≈øe of Peeres, yet that is aboli≈øht as incongruous to their calling. And then why may not the removall of their Eccle≈øia≈øticall juri≈ødiction be con≈øented to, as well, if it prove inconvenient and prejudiciall to the Church? The abolition of the one is no more again≈øt the oath, then of the other.

Againe, when this oath was framed, the Church was indued with the ignorance of the times, with divers unlawfull immunities, in all which re≈øpects the oath was invalid, being vinculum iniquitatis, and ≈øome were pared off as light ≈øhined forth. And why may not the great Revenues of the Bi≈øhops with their ≈øole juri≈ødiction in ≈øo large a circuit, be indicted and convict to be again≈øt the edification of the Church; and it be found more for the glory of God, that both the Revenue be divided to maintaine a preaching Mini≈øtery, and their juri≈ødiction al≈øo, for the better over≈øight and cen≈øure of manners. And then is there as good a plea, notwith≈øtanding the oath, to alter this u≈øele≈ø≈øe Anti-Evangelicall pompe and domination of a few, as to antiquate other immunities ari≈øing from the errour of the times, not the tenure of Scripture. Were indeed the priviledges in que≈øtion, ≈øuch as were for the advantage of the Church, to further her edification; or had the Prelates been good Stewards and innocent in the u≈øe of them; then had the plea carried a fairer ≈øhew: But there having been ≈øo many forfeitures by abu≈øe, and tho≈øe great promotions and juri≈ødictions, being as unwieldy to a Spirituall ≈øouldier, as Sauls Armour to David; and ≈øo doe not further, but hinder the work of the Go≈øpel, where ≈øtrong holds are to be vanqui≈øht not by carnall pompe, but ≈øpirituall furniture mighty through God, 2 Cor. 10.4. I ≈øee no ju≈øt ingagement to maintaine ≈øuch comber≈øome greatne≈ø≈øe, adding onely glory to the per≈øon, not vigour to the maine work of a Mini≈øter of the Go≈øpel.

Againe, thus I angue. If the King may con≈øent to alter the Lawes of the Nation, notwith≈øtanding his oath, then ≈øo he may al≈øo the Clergies immunities. For tho≈øe rights and immunities, they either
hold them by Law or otherwi≈øe. If by Law, then the Parliament which hath power to alter all Lawes, have power to alter ≈øuch Lawes as give them their immunities, and tho≈øe Lawes altered, the immunity cea≈øeth, and ≈øo the Kings ingagement in that particular. If their immunity be not by Law, it is either an u≈øurpation without ju≈øt title, which upon di≈øcovery is null. Or it was given by Papall power in times of darkne≈ø≈øe, which being an Antichri≈øtian u≈øurpation is long ≈øince aboli≈øht in this Kingdome.

p.hi: The Author illu≈øtrateth the force of his argument by an example holding forth an inconvenience. Where publique Faith is given for money, it is not relea≈øeable by Parliament, without con≈øent of the party: for if it be, it is in effect no engagement: ≈øo &c.

div.p: An. There's a great deale of difference between an ingagement made to per≈øons, on valuable con≈øideration, and that which is made gratis to an office or ≈øociety ≈øub≈øervient to publike good. Of the former kinde, is the ingagement to pay ≈øummes of money of whom they were borrowed for publike good, which is indi≈øpen≈øable without the con≈øent of the lender? Of the latter ≈øort, is this ingagement to the Engli≈øh Clergy. Now ingagements to a Society to maintaine their rights, indulged for the per≈øonall worth of pre≈øent incumbents, or to promote the u≈øefulne≈ø≈øe of that office. If in their matters they prove prejudiciall to the office, or the ≈øucceeding officers by their ill demeanour forfeit them, their ingagement becomes alterable: There's no inju≈øtice done to make a Law to overrule, or alter this ingagement. There's no que≈øtion of power in the Parliament to over-rule it: for in the former ca≈øe of money, if King and Parliament ≈øhould ordaine relea≈øe of the ingagement, the ingagement were gone in Law though not in equity; The Order would be valid in Law though injurious: So if there be no injurie, the King and Parliament may cancell any obligation. And where there is forfeiture by mi≈øcarriage, or the priviledge indulged to a Mini≈øtery (which ought to hold nothing but for publike good) proves prejudiciall; the abrogation will be ju≈øt as well as Legall, there will be no injury done.

But take it at the wor≈øt, it is but for the King to get the Clergies con≈øent, and I hope in this ca≈øe they will not be ≈øo tenacious of their wealth, and honour, as to let the Crowne runne an hazard rather then lay down their Mitres, and indanger the whole Land to be
brought to nothing rather then them≈øelves to moderation: I cannot but have a better conceit of the major part of them at this time, which will amount to a con≈øent, and that in this Authors judgement takes off the ≈øcruple about the oath.

p.hi: Be≈øides this Argument, there be other in≈øinuations brought in by the faine Author, that it would be di≈øhonourable to the Kings memory, to be an unfortunate in≈øtrument to pull downe Cathedralls, and impoveri≈øh them, &c.

div.p: An≈ø. To aboli≈øh Prelacy, and ≈øeize the revenues of Prelates to private or civill Intere≈øt, undoubtedly could neither want ≈øtaine nor guilt. Such kind of impropriation as happened in the dayes of Henry the eight was cried out of all the Chri≈øtian world over. Illam bonorum Eccle≈øia≈øticorum di≈ø≈øipationem cum dete≈øtando ≈øacrilegio conjunctam, tecum, & cum bonis omnibus deploramus, ≈øcelus univer≈øo erbi commune, ≈øaith Beza in re≈øp. ad Sarac. de gradibus mini≈øt. pag. ult. But who knowes not the great defect among≈øt us, of congruous maintenance for parochiall Pa≈øtors, by whom the worke of the Mini≈øtery is chiefly to be performed? And if tho≈øe large revenues of the Prelates were diverted to ≈øupply with ≈øufficient maintenance all the defective Pari≈øhes in England, there would be no danger of Sacriledge: And this would not be to ruine, but to rectifie the devotion of former ages, and turne pompe into u≈øe, and impediments into helps. A work, for which following generations ≈øhould not need to pity the King, as put upon it by misfortune: but ri≈øe up and c ‚Ä¢ ll him ble≈ø≈øed, who≈øe many other di≈øa≈øters ended in ≈øo good, and u≈øefull a work.

Had the motives of Heary the eight been as hone≈øt to ca≈øt off Papall u≈øurpation, as the Act was holy; and the improvement of Abby Lands, as conformable to Divine Law, as the di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies to the Rules of Divine wi≈ødome; He might not onely have been honourable in our Annals: but if I may ≈øo ≈øpeak, a Saint in our Calender. It was the defective circum≈øtances of actions in them≈øelves glorious, which made them a di≈øhonour to him, though advantagious to the Church, which ill circum≈øtances being avoided in the thing in que≈øtion, God and good men will highly approve it, which is the onely reall, and regardable honour. Thus far my fir≈øt opponent.

My ≈øecond Antagoni≈øt exceeds the fir≈øt, both in ≈øubtlety, and peremptorine≈ø≈øe;
for he plainly affirmes,A Book called The review of the covenant. pag. 72. 73. 74. that the King cannot de≈øert Epi≈øcopacy without flat perjury; and hence falls foule, both on tho≈øe that would force him to it, and al≈øo on tho≈øe moderate Courtiers that for peace ≈øake coun≈øeld it. He di≈øputes thus There's difference between Lawes and Oathes; where the ≈øupreme jus Dominii is, there is a power above all Lawes, but not above their owne Oathes, in whom that power is; for Law bindes onely while it is a Law, that is, till it be repealed. But an Oath bindes as long as it plea≈øeth him to whom it is taken: The rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the ≈øubject of ≈øupreme Power may cedere jure ≈øuo, and oblige him≈øelfe where before he was free: which if they doe by promi≈øe, Ju≈øtice bindes them to performance; but if by an Oath (the matter being lawfull) then are they bound in Religion, and Con≈øcience, for an Oath addes a religious bond unto God. If this were not ≈øo, no Oath were binding to them.

I an≈øwer. Fir≈øt, it's a ground laid downe by this Author in the ≈øame place; that no Oath is obligatory beyond the intention of it; and then I fir≈øt propo≈øe it to con≈øideration, whether the intention of this Oath be not only again≈øt a tyrannous inva≈øion on the rights of the Clergy, not again≈øt an orderly alteration of them, if any prove inconvenient, and to protect them again≈øt violence, not again≈øt legall wayes of change. For, fir≈øt, this is as much as it is rationall for a King to undertake, and therefore in right rea≈øon the Oath ≈øhould have no other ≈øen≈øe, if the words of the Oath will beare it, as the words of this Oath will. Secondly, this Oath to the Clergy, mu≈øt not be intended in a ≈øen≈øe incon≈øi≈øtent with the Kings Oath to the people, fir≈øt taken for their protection in their Lawes, and Liberties; for then the latter Oath would be a pre≈øent breach of the former, and ≈øo unlawfull. Now one of the priviledges of the people is, that the Peeres and Commons in Parliament, have power with the con≈øent of the King, to alter whatever in any particular e≈øtate is inconvenient to the whole. And therefore he cannot afterwards ingage him≈øelfe to any partionlar e≈øtate, to exempt it from this power; for by that Oath at lea≈øt ce≈ø≈øit jure ≈øuo, in this Authors judgement. The Clergy and their priviledges are ≈øubject to the Parliament, or they are not; I hope they will not now claime an exemption from ≈øecular power. But if they be under Parliamentary power, how can it rationally be conceived to be the meaning of the Kings Oath, to pre≈øerve the priviledges of the Clergy, again≈øt
that power to which they are legally ≈øubject? or how were the Oath in that ≈øen≈øe con≈øi≈øtent with the priviledges of the Nation, formerly ≈øworn to by the King? If the Oath had ≈øuch a ≈øen≈øe in the times of Popery, when the Clergy were a di≈øtinct corporation; yet when that exemption was aboli≈øht, as a branch of Antichri≈øtian u≈øurpation, the change of their condition mu≈øt needs change the intention of the Oath, unle≈ø≈øe they will ≈øay, that the Crown ≈øtands ≈øtill ingaged to them, to maintaine ≈øuch priviledges, as by Act of Parliament were long ≈øince aboli≈øht; which is to make his Oath to them contrariant to that taken before, for the maintenance of the again≈øt legall alteration of their priviledges by Parliament, makes it unlawfull, and ≈øo not obligatory. And if it be not intended again≈øt legall alteration, the King may pa≈ø≈øe a Bill for the abolition of Epi≈øcopacy, when his Hou≈øes of Parliament think it convenient, and petition for it without violation of his Oath.

Secondly, I an≈øwer from the expre≈ø≈øions in the Oath it ≈øelfe, as they are ≈øet downe by the ≈øame Author, pag. 74. To protect the Bi≈øhops, and their priviledges to his power, as every good King in his Kingdome in right ought to protect, and defend the Bi≈øhops, and Churches under their government. Here you ≈øee the engagement put upon the King, is but to his power, as every good King ought in right to protect, &c. Now ≈øuch power is no further then he can doe it without ≈øinning again≈øt God, and being injurious to the re≈øt of his people. When then he hath interpo≈øed his Authority for them, and put forth all the power he hath to pre≈øerve them; if after all this he mu≈øt let them fall, or ≈øupport them with the blood of his good Subjects, and tho≈øe unwilling too to ingage their lives for the others priviledges; I thinke none need que≈øtion, but that he hath gone to the extent of his power, and as farre as good Kings are bound in right, for it is not equall to ingage the lives of ≈øome to uphold the honour of others; that were to be cruell to many thou≈øands, to be indulgent to a few.
